Their DPA says detailed reports/certificates are provided to customers on request (confidentially). If you need certified scope language, request the SOC/ISO/HITRUST report via CoreWeave (or through your contract/DPA). (docs.coreweave.com, coreweave.com) If you want, I can (a) request the specific scope language template to ask CoreWeave for, or (b) help draft an audit/contract request to obtain the confidential reports.

[143] Research Agent 🔍 Q: As of August 14, 2025, what termination-for-convenience, step-down, or take-or-pay minimum commitment provisions have been publicly disclosed for CoreWeave’s material hyperscaler customer contracts other than the 2025 OpenAI GPU supply agreement, including any minimum annual spend or capacity guarantees and associated cure periods? A: Short answer — publicly disclosed non‑OpenAI terms are limited to the Microsoft Master Services Agreement and CoreWeave’s IPO disclosures: - Microsoft MSA (filed as Exhibit 10.23; effective Feb 22, 2023) — reserved‑instance / “Reserved Instances” model (i.e., dedicated/take‑or‑pay style capacity via Order Forms), payment/upfront payment mechanics (some fields redacted), termination-for-cause only with a 45‑day cure period, termination‑period payment rules (Customer pays for services during transfer/termination period), and suspension rules (2 consecutive business days triggers cancellation of payment obligations for affected services). No general termination‑for‑convenience clause is shown in the public MSA. (sec.gov) - CoreWeave S‑1 / IPO filings — describe that most material customer contracts are multi‑year (2–5 years), “take‑or‑pay” in form, include customer prepayments (weighted average 15–25% of TCV) and $15.1B RPO as of Dec 31, 2024; the filings do not disclose granular minimum‑annual‑spend or step‑down guarantees or cure periods for other hyperscalers. (sec.gov) I did not find publicly filed, unredacted MSAs or Order Forms for other hyperscalers (AWS, Google, Meta) that disclose specific minimum‑spend, step‑down or take‑or‑pay cure details as of Aug 14, 2025. If you want, I can pull the specific MSA clauses and line references.

[144] Research Agent 🔍 Q: What days sales outstanding (DSO) and accounts receivable aging metrics did CoreWeave report for Q2 2025, and did management disclose any changes to customer payment terms or receivables concentration after quarter-end? I found no management disclosure of any change to customer payment terms or receivables concentration after quarter‑end in the Q2 2025 Form 10‑Q, the Aug 12, 2025 earnings release or the earnings call transcript. (sec.gov, investors.coreweave.com, investing.com)

[147] Research Agent 🔍 Q: In 2024–2025 disclosures, what proportion of CoreWeave’s projected electricity consumption is covered by power price hedging instruments or fixed-price/indexed power contracts, and what percentage of customer compute agreements include power cost pass-through or indexation clauses? A: Short answer: CoreWeave’s 2024–2025 public filings do not disclose a numeric percentage for either metric. Its S‑1/10‑Q say the company entered PPAs in 2023–2024 and report contracted power (≈1.3 GW at 12/31/2024; ~1.6 GW by 3/31/2025) and that the team “hedg(es) and risk manages power costs,” but they do not state what share of projected electricity is price‑hedged or fixed‑priced/index‑linked. Likewise, CoreWeave’s filings describe committed customer contracts and (in related Core Scientific hosting slides) that certain HPC hosting agreements treat power as a direct pass‑through, but the company does not quantify the % of customer compute agreements that include power cost pass‑through or indexation. (sec.gov, content.equisolve.net)

[150] Research Agent 🔍 Q: As of August 14, 2025, what is CoreWeave’s debt maturity schedule by instrument and amount from 2025 through 2030, and have any maturities been amended or extended since year-end 2024? A: Short answer (as of Aug 14, 2025): - 2025: 2024 Term Loan $1.0bn (accelerated and repaid Apr 11, 2025). No material parent-level senior debt scheduled remaining in 2025. (sec.gov) - 2026: OEM equipment financings (aggregate notional ≈ $1.5bn as of 3/31/25) with maturities roughly Mar 2026–Oct 2027 (timing by contract). (sec.gov) - 2027: Revolver previously due Jun 21, 2027 (but see amendment below); some OEM tranches to Oct 2027. (sec.gov) - 2028: DDTL 1.0 — ~$1.8975bn (final balloon Mar 2028); Revolving credit (drawn balance ~$50m as of 3/31/25) — amended (see). (sec.gov) - 2029: DDTL 2.0 — ~$4.3863bn (final May 2029). (sec.gov) - 2030: Senior unsecured notes $2.0bn due Jun 1, 2030 (closed May 27, 2025) plus a $2.6bn delayed-draw term loan (DDTL 3.0) maturing Aug 21, 2030 (closed Jul 31, 2025). (investors.coreweave.com) Have maturities been amended/extended since YE‑2024? Yes — material changes include the Revolving Credit amendment (increased to $1.5bn and extended to May 2, 2028, with a springing earlier date in certain circumstances), repayment/acceleration or termination of certain term loans, and new issuances (2030 notes and DDTL‑3.0). (sec.gov, investors.coreweave.com) If you want, I can produce a one‑page table with exact instrument names, outstanding principals and citations.
